sections.heading: Abstract
sections.text:
In this work, heterostructures formed with vertical stacking of two-dimensional
(2D) layered materials are systematically studied. Considering near-infrared (NIR)
/ short wave-infrared (SWIR) photodetection, van der Waals (vdW) heterostructures
with various possible combinations of group-6 and group-7 monolayer transition metal
dichalcogenides (TMDs) are explored. Single layer distorted 1T ReS2, being a dynamically stable semiconducting material, is adopted as the group-7 constituent. On the

sections.heading: Introduction
sections.text:
Over the past few years, exploration of various two-dimensional (2D) layered materials, has
spurred enormous research interest in the elds of electronics, optoelectronics and electrochemical energy storage.1 10 2D materials like graphene, hBN, transition metal dichalco-
genides (TMDs), and black phosphorus could be extremely useful for realizing low power, high speed next generation optoelectronic devices.2,11 13 Owing to distinct photoelectric prop-
erties and higher mechanical exibility, 2D materials can also be easily integrated with exible substrates.14,15 Besides, vertical stacking of atomically thin 2D materials may o er strong
interlayer coupling, spontaneous exciton dissociation as well as fast charge transfer across the heterointerface.1,13,16,17
For the purpose of designing ultrafast NIR and SWIR photodetectors, in this study, we
have explored the vertical stacking of monolayer ReS2 (a group-7 TMD) on top of the single layer group-6 TMDs e.g. MoS2, WS2, MoSe2, WSe2, and MoTe2 (Fig. 1). It is worth mentioning that distinctive optical properties owing to reduced screening e ect and strong
light-matter interaction, make the monolayer and the fewlayer TMDs promising candidates for next generation optoelectronic devices.17 19 Responsivity, detectivity and response time
are the parameters which largely determine the performance of any photodetector. In order
to achieve high gain, we need to look for a device where generation and separation of carriers are enabled by direct or, near-direct bandgap and large band o sets.15,20 Besides, intrinsic

Weak screening in monolayer TMDs leads to a large exciton binding energy, hence requiring an e cient mechanism for exciton dissociation into free carriers.18,19 Excitons in TMDs can be of various types e.g. bright excitons (involving K and K′ points of the Brillouin zone (BZ)), nonzero center of mass momentum excitons,23 and dark intervalley excitons.18,24 In
order to model interacting electron-hole pairs, we need many-body perturbation theories such as Hedin's GW approximation25 and Bethe-Salpeter equation26 for charged and neutral excitons respectively.18,27 However, in this work, we have emphasized mainly on the
selection of group-6 and group-7 monolayer TMDs to develop geometrically optimized atom-
istic models of vdW heterostructures. Considering the large geometry optimized composite
supercells, we have restricted our study within the framework of density functional theory

We compare various performance metrics of group-6/group-7 vdW heterostructures utilizing

The primary goal of this study is to guide the selection of group-6 TMDs which not
only form type-II band alignments but also exhibit large band o sets, while forming vertical
heterostructures with a group-7 TMD e.g. distorted 1T ReS2. It is important to realize here that the atomically thin pn junctions based on such vdW heterointerfaces with large band o sets, exhibit e cient separation of photogenerated e− (electrons) and h+ (holes).28 30 So
far, several studies have been reported in literature delineating the type-II band alignment of vdW heterostructures (e.g. vertical heterostructures with monolayer WS2/MoS2,16 vdW p-n junctions with p-type WSe2 and n-type MoS2,17 SnSe/MoS2 vdW heterostructures,29 multilayer ReSe2/MoS2 p-n heterointerfaces,31 fewlayer ReS2/WSe2 heterointerface,32 black phosphorus-MoS2 heterostructure,33 and MoTe2/MoS2 p-n heterojunction34). Apart from those, type-I (heterostructure with MoS2/ReS2 monolayers)35 and type-III (BP/ReS2 heterojunction)36 band alignments have also been investigated.
However, a systematic study of vdW heterostructures with various possible combinations of
group-6 and group-7 monolayer TMDs has not yet been conducted. Here, we opt for single
layer distorted 1T ReS2 as the group-7 constituent and semiconducting monolayer TMDs e.g. MoS2, WS2, MoSe2, WSe2, and MoTe2 as the group-6 constituents, and model their vertical stacks to demonstrate electronic properties of group-6/group-7 vdW heterointer-
faces. Among di erent group-6/group-7 combinations, we show that both ReS2/MoSe2 and ReS2/WSe2 heterostructures lead to signi cantly enhanced photodetection metrics. Further, larger ∆EC and ∆EV values at the type-II heterointerface will ensure e cient separation of charge carriers, and hence higher responsivity for the ReS2/WSe2 vertical stack.

sections.heading: Methodology
sections.text:
In this study, rst-principles based DFT calculations were performed using the software package QuantumATK .37 All electronic structure calculations and geometry optimizations
were carried out using the generalized gradient approximation (GGA) as exchange correlation along with the Perdew-Burke-Ernzerhof (PBE) functional.38 Besides, Grimme's dispersion
correction (DFTD2) was employed to include the e ects of vdW interactions among di erent monolayers.39 This highly accurate scheme can describe systems with medium to large in-
teratomic distances, and has been utilized for dispersion correction in multilayer TMDs and TMD based heterostructures.34,39,40 For the norm-conserving pseudopotentials, OPENMX (Open source package for Material eXplorer) code was employed.41,42 The basis sets for Mo,
W and Re were taken as s3p2d1 , whereas those for S, Se, and Te atoms were s2p2d1 ,
s2p2d1 , and s2p2d2f1 respectively. Apart from this, k-points in the Monkhorst-Pack grid were set to 9×9×1 (X-Y-Z) for the unit cells and 9×9×3 for the heterostructures. The
density mesh cut-o value was set to 200 Hartree. Furthermore, to avoid spurious interac-
tion between periodic images, su cient vacuum was incorporated along the perpendicular
direction (normal to the X-Y plane).
In order to optimize geometries of the unit cells and the vdW heterostructures, the
LBFGS (Limited-memory Broyden Fletcher Goldfarb Shanno) algorithm was utilized. All
the structures were fully optimized with force and stress tolerance values of 0.01 eV/Å and 0.001 eV/Å3 respectively. For vdW heterostructures, the mean absolute strain values on
both the monolayer surfaces were calculated as 0.70%, 0.70%, 0.59%, 0.61%, and 0.68% for
ReS2/MoS2, ReS2/WS2, ReS2/MoSe2, ReS2/WSe2, and ReS2/MoTe2 respectively. The surface matching algorithm described in,43 was utilized to obtain low-strain heterointerfaces.
The vdW heterostructures were then fully relaxed using the LBFGS algorithm. It is worth mentioning that the LBFGS algorithm is very competitive owing to its low iteration cost.44
It took a nite number of iterations to attain the de ned force and stress tolerance values

Constituent materials: group-6 and group-7 TMDs
Monolayer distorted 1T ReS2
ReS2 is a group-7 TMD which has distinctive structural, electrical and optical properties.47 49 One extra electron of `Re' leads to the formation of `Re'-`Re' bonds which in turn create diamond-shaped (DS) parallel chains (with an angle of ∼119.8◦ between a and b axes).47 49
It is important to note that the monolayer distorted ReSe2 is also a near direct semiconductor with low symmetry and geometrical anisotropy. However, bandgap of ReSe2 is somewhat smaller (1.34 eV) than that of ReS2.50

sections.heading: Stability and optical absorption
sections.text:
Since existence of negative frequencies in phonon bandstructure, or phonon density of states
